review: My 2009 Samsung Large TV used "widgets" to connect to the net and allowed me to link to Amazon for movies and TV shows. Suddenly, a few weeks ago I could not connect to the net. Ultimately, I traced this fault back to Samsung and was told that because of the prevalence of apps vis-a-vis widgets, Samsumg no longer supported widgets and there was no "fix" at that time (and probably is none now). I checked the alternatives.and, based on reviews, the choice narrowed down to Amazon Fire TV or the latest generation Roku. The Fire has the ability to use voice for selections, etc and that is worth its weight in gold. So we opted for the Fire and have not been disappointed. It connects to the net easily and there is no apparent buffering time which makes watching movies or episodes a dream. It appears to lack some apps and, hence, I opted for 4 stars and not five. Just as a note, while we have WiFi in our home, we have long used internet over the powerline (house wiring) and connect by ethernet and ethernet speeds.  We have used the Western Digital Powerline Adapters (available at Amazon) but there are many other brands out in the market place.

review: Purchased Fire TV hooked up and worked fine for 3 days then no sound from optical cable to amplifier. Amplifier showed it had a signal but no sound, called to technical service spent over 3 calls over 3 hrs. changing every setting possible with no results. Amazon sent out a new Fire TV hooked it up and it did not work right out of the box still no sound to amplifier. Checked Amplifier and optical cable all worked with Blue-ray & over the air TV programs. I got a reply from tec. that my amplifier is too old to work with Fire TV Dolby Digital Plus, but it did work for the first 3 days would like to know if it worked for 3 days, how did it all of a sudden become too old to work. I am disappointed that Amazon touts the fact that they are the only ones with the Dolby Digital sound and they blame my system that worked for 3 days with the Fire TV for being at fault.
